titleInfo.title: Microwave Spectroscopy of Semiconductor Hosted Two-Dimensional Electron Systems

mods:mods.abstract: This dissertation explores several aspects of microwave spectroscopy of two-dimensional electron systems (2DES), motivated by the microwave signatures of Wigner crystal phases that can exist in these systems. The spectroscopy is carried out by means of coplanar waveguide transmission lines patterned onto the top of semiconductor samples. Wigner crystals form from otherwise mobile charge carriers when inter-carrier Coulomb repulsion overwhelms the kinetic energy. This occurs when the 2DES is sufficiently dilute, for low temperature and small disorder. These solids are insulating due to pinning by disorder, and in the rf or microwave range exhibit "pinning'' modes, in which pieces of the crystal oscillate within the disorder potential. In high magnetic fields these pinning modes are known to be sharp and can vary widely in frequency. I describe high magnetic field measurements of a series of nominally identical devices with unprecedented low disorder and which only vary in the thickness of the quantum well that house the 2DES. This research has demonstrated the lowest frequency pinning mode observed to date, and further shows that the pinning is due to alloy disorder in the confining barriers that form the quantum well. A self consistent model of the wave functions of the quantum wells gives a good explanation of the pinning frequency as a function of well thickness. Wigner crystals are predicted to form in zero magnetic field as well, although at much lower carrier densities, and should have microwave signatures. An excellent candidate for housing such a solid is AlAs. In exploring 2DES in AlAs to search for microwave signatures of Wigner crystallization at zero magnetic field, we found a novel type of cyclotron resonance, in which plasma shift due to finite sample size is absent In another step toward studying 2DES at extremely low carrier density I developed a new type of transmission line, a coplanar waveguide whose slots are filled with resistive film, a resistively loaded coplanar waveguide (RLCPW), to measure 2DES. The RLCPW applied to the sample hosting the 2DES provides a uniform metallic surface serving as a gate, to control the areal density of the 2DES. As a demonstration of this technique I present measurements on a Si metal oxide field effect transistors (MOSFET) showing that the RLCPW can be used for quantitative measurements of 2DES microwave conductivity, and additionally measured a heterojunction insulated gate field effect transistor (HIGFET), a type of device that is particularly promising for study of zero magnetic field Wigner crystals.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Lloyd Engel, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Irinel Chiorescu, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Geoffrey Strouse, University Representative; Nicholas Bonesteel, Committee Member; Sergio Almaraz-Calderon, Committee Member.
